[h1]A classic game that does not need introductions.[/h1]

This is a classic that defined its genre, and 16 years after its release is still very enjoyable.

The "source" version of it is a reimplementation of the original game on Valve's then new engine and offers a slightly better graphic experience, although much of the visual artifacts have been left unchanged, with low-count polygons models and low-res textures.

In terms of gameplay one has to think to how computers and games were back in 1998.  Seen with modern eyes some of the game mechanics are repetitive (especially towards the end, where increased difficult = more badass monsters from previous levels to kill), but again, if you are going to play this game now you should definitively approach it as a movie-goer would approach a black&white film from the 40's.

TLDR: Great game, dated graphics, horrible bugs/glitches in this version. I recommend playing the original.

The benefits in this version are mostly water effects, slight lightning improvements, enemy ragdolling and easier object pulling/pushing. Most of the disadvantages are listed below.
The story is simple and the game's got many weird elements compared to the current FPS's, but it's still a great game and a classic. Looks like it takes like 9 hours to complete when you loot every place, but know where to go and what to do.

To list a of a few really annoying or game breaking things, many compared to original Half-Life:
-HITBOX/HIT REGISTERING PROBLEMS!
    -The blast pit monster doesn't do damage to you or the security guard who's supposed to die.
    -The leeches have almost non existent hitbox.
    -The helicopter doesn't seem to register hits from gauss or RPG (didn't get it to even smoke).
    -The gonarch or whatever has a crappy hit registering.
    -The final boss has a crappy hitbox (I have beaten him in normal half-life with hard difficulty many times and this was 5 times harder in easy difficulty)
-HORRIBLE VISUAL ARTIFACTS in "residue processing" and somewhere else too.
-NPCs go "YAARRG" every 0.5 seconds if they are damaged.
-The crowbar makes a metal hitting sound when you hit any object and so gets really irritating when destroying boxes.
-The boxes take more time to break with crowbar, which adds to the previous annoyance.
-You jump higher than you should (IE You can jump crouch straight on top of a box in the laser tripmine building)
-The barnacles lower their tongue really slowly, but they can catch you when their tongue isn't lowered yet. This leads to some funny scary moments though.
-Missing dialog/AI problems.

And if you're new to Half-Life (and don't know whats supposed to happen or where to go):
-You can jump crouch above one vent in "we've got hostiles" vent maze section, get behind a fence and get stuck in an area you've been before (your auto saves will get replaced by the being stuck ones too).
-You see only blackness through the dam turbines, which has lead people to think it's not the right way and get stuck.
-You can shoot the scientist through the glass in "apprehension" and the game doesn't end, so you can't get the door open.
-The missing dialog/AI problems can really confuse you.

If you're hard-core and want the authentic Half-Life experience, buy the cds and patch the game to 1.1.1.0, cause the steam "original" version is bugged in many ways too nowadays. I would actually say that this Source version has better working AI in general than the other steam version.

Si vous découvrez ce jeu, tentez plutôt l'original (Half-Life tout court)  sinon lisez les critiques de Half-Life Source AVANT de tenter le remake qui n'apporte rien (certainement pas une meilleur expérience de jeu, ni de magnifiques graphismes comme on serait en droit de l'attendre, ni même rien de notable d'ailleurs.. en dehors de nouveaux bugs qui n'existaient pas à l'époque d'Hal-Life).

Half-Life Source est donc une erreur, une divergeance temporelle, un accident cosmique : il n'apporte rien et pire encore il :

- supprime certain détails (moins gore par exemple)
- rend les temps de chargements carrément plus longs et détestables entre chaque niveaux, lag en pleine action à cause de la même raison
- lisse la difficulté qui devient en mode le plus dur clairement casual (je suspecte la sélection de la difficulté d'être buggée puisque c'est un jeu d'enfant en mode extrême..........) 
- sans parler d'éléments de jeu originaux qui ont disaprus
- contrairement aux nombreux bugs qui eux se sont invités en famille....

...et surtout le remake Source rend ridicule l'eau ou textures soit disant HD car au final, le jeu reste vieux et ceux qui veulent découvrir cet excellent jeu devraient se tourner vers l'original pour au moins une raison : c'est l'original en bien et en mal! Et il est complet au moins, et intègre.

Le seul avantage du Source c'est de gérer les écrans plus larges mais à quel prix ? L'original n'est pas pour autant déformé sur écran pano (juste des bords noirs sur les côtés).

L'argument des nouvelles textures n'est donc pas recevable : ce remake Source reste tout aussi out-dated visuellement (donc aucun intérêt sur ce point précis, vous ne baverez pas plus que devant l'original), les textures HD ne changent rien et n'ont rien de HD en réalité (elles sont même peu homogènes avec certaines plus laides que d'autres)..

C'esr assez honteux en fait.. Même ceux qui ne connaissaient pas ce jeu, n'auraient rien à gagner à jouer avec Source, ce faux HD qui dénature l'original. 

Petits jeunes découvrant cette mythique série, ne vous laissez pas abuser par les promesses du HD, elles ne sont pas tenues et imposent trop de nouvelles restrictions (lenteur des chargement, disparition d'éléments) pour pouvoir vivre l'expérience originelle de Half-Life.

1998, I was 18, Id been weened on the Spectrum, then the Amiga.  I got my PC in 1996 and for two years played pretty ropey demos, and sometimes good stuff, like Theme Park.  Then I picked up half life.  Lifechanger.

What can I say?  The intro scene setting, the journey in on the monorail, the voice welcoming you to your working day, the sound design... THE SOUND DESIGN.  I think thats what got me.  Im a music producer by trade and even 18 year old me was blown away by the score, and sound effects.  The levels on Xen, the sounds made, the voice of the Nihilanth, it was all too perfect.  

This game holds up today, yep, graphically its a little jaded, but i still play, and I mean this source version, not the Black Mesa update.

Некоторые аспекты искусственного интеллекта Half-Life 2 могут быть заметны в Half-Life: Source. Например, противники более внимательны к присутствию игрока и ищут укрытие при ранениях. Также следует заметить, что союзники следуют за игроком на манер того, как это было в Half-Life 2. При встрече с противниками, вместо того, чтобы всегда оставаться на месте или умереть самим, союзники разобщаются, когда игрок идёт дальше. Однако, в отличие от Half-Life 2, команды управления группой союзников отстутствуют. В некоторых случаях изменённый искусственный интеллект неблагоприятно затрагивает игровой процесс, конфликтуя с работой некоторых скриптовых сценок из оригинальной игры.

Well this is... unnecessary. Alright, so the original Half-Life was an incredible game and still is. For the time, the graphics were pretty good, and the combat was fluid. As for Half-Life source... well... it's interesting. On one hand, it adds little details that enhance the graphics and gameplay (enhanced bullet hole/blood textures, Source physics, enhanced water, etc...), but on the other hand, the game is filled TO THE BRIM with bugs and glitches that weren't in the original. In some cases, the bugs can actually BREAK THE GAME. For example: On occasion, if you respawn after you die, you will spawn with NO WEAPONS. The game also seems to be signifcantly harder than the original. Now normally, this wouldn't seem so bad, but chapters such as "We've got hostiles", and ANY of the Xen levels really become a chore. Overall, if you're going to buy Half-Life, buy the original. In all reality, you should only really buy this for some Garry's Mod content. In the end, I am going to give this a 5/10. I would recommend it if you completed the original, and would like a level select. otherwise, stick to the original.

This is basically [url=http://store.steampowered.com/recommended/recommendgame/70]Half-Life[/url] with an actual physics engine. As it is, this version is more for people who want to experience Half-Life with some more modern conceits. (The Source version of Half-Life Deathmatch is [url=http://store.steampowered.com/recommended/recommendgame/360]separate[/url].)

The physics engine in question is Valve's Source engine, which means adjustable field-of-view, higher resolution displays, ragdoll physics, and more realistic water that you can see into somewhat (which [i]kind of[/i] ruins the scenes with the Icthyosaurs, kind of). There is also Oculus Rift support.

The MP5 functions slightly differently: it bounces up and down more in your hands when it fires, and the bullets fly accordingly. The weapons, IMO, are even more satisfying overall than in the original version.

The port itself isn't stellar. There are some texture, scripting and AI glitches that you may or may not experience, since subsequent updates to the engine were not kind to HL Source. I clipped out of the tram in the beginning once!


Aside from an optional HD texture pack, the ability to use certain game assets in Garry's Mod, the ability to start a new game from any chapter, and animated menu screens displaying scenes from the game...that's it. Those are the only things separating HL: Source from the original game. It's interesting overall, and I think it [i]feels[/i] great if not better than the original game, but this is by all means more of an enthusiast purchase. Ross Scott used it to make [url=http://www.accursedfarms.com/movies/fm/]Freeman's Mind[/url], at least.

Others were more disappointed after the initial release. That disappointment spurred the development of a fan-made recreation called Black Mesa, which is much more of a modern remake. It's free to download [url=http://www.blackmesasource.com/]here[/url], and an enhanced version is [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/362890/]available on Steam[/url].

In this review, I'll be going over the goods and bads of Half-Life: Source. first, the goods: it's on the Source engine (Half-Life 2's engine), which means it feature alot more core features such as ragdolls, jigglebones, some of the decals, sounds, etc. it also takes advantage of the higher limits and redoes some of the levels (brighter light settings, Surface Tension now has a full canyon following much longer pipes, Apprehension now has blue barrels that need to be released to make a broken ramp float, etc), NPCs can cast shadows, many bugs (press E on objects through walls) have been fixed, Water is now see-through partially, and Headcrabs can be killed in a single hit from the crowbar. now, while these all sound pretty cool, there are many downsides. the same graphics from Half-Life (Goldsource) are used. these old graphics don't fit with the overall realisticness of the Source engine. no NPC has any sort of death animation (which could have been done as seen in Half-Life 2 with the Antlion Guard's staggering-to-ground animation) instead defaulting to the free-falling ragdoll, the gore from Half-Life 2 just doesn't fit with the low-quality cartoon-ish looking gibs and walls of Half-Life 1, and certain NPCs lack any stunning animations as seen in HL:GS. overall, this doesn't really feel much like Half-Life, but just a 3rd party clone. it's not really that great unless you have a low-end PC unable to run Black Mesa. otherwise, skip this one unless you are looking to finish your Half-Life game collection.

Half-LIfe: Source is a, ehem, "remake" of Half-Life 1, which in this case means "we took HL1 recources and transfered them off GoldSrc engine to Source Engine". And yes, it contains single-player campaign of HL1... DeathMatch portion was released serapately later. Though now that you can only purchase bundle of Source with DM, it doesn't matter much. Yes, it comes with HD models from Blue Shift bundled

So, what remake brought? Nothing major. Just small things here and there. First, default things from engine changes - dynamic shadows from flashlight that HL2 Episode 2 brought into engine, for example. There is more of metallic reflective textures, that look ugly in the darkness. The water was changed into HL2 style one... Means more transperency yet the rippling animation was removed. Enemies don't have death animations anymore - they use ragdoll... Which sometimes looks clunky with low-polygon monsters. There are even occasional decoration object that now uses physics, like hooked boxes. And you don't throw boxes away over the hills when you try to move box sideways. At least it all comes along with HD Models pack from Blue Shift.
One of the non-graphics changes got to be improved AI, which I also think came. NPCs always react finely, while in original they would often first turn around slowly to face the threat. Security officers that follow you don't get lost as easily, you can even forget about babysitting them. And where in original they had "shoot at some aliens" as high priority, "follow the player" seems to be higher one in this remake... Which means that they will not shoot a thing if they will be busy following strafing player. Guards are better at guard duty, yep. On one of the notes, flying enemy with huge brain in final parts of games is now more aggresive, attempting to get into your face, all the time!
Some of the damage values were changed. The biggest example got to be clowbar, it got buffed... Now, just like in HL2, it takes only one hit of this tool to bring down Headcrabs and Barnacles.
Some of small bugs in HL1 were fixed, some new small bugs were added. Oh yea, and music stops when you go to the next area. 
But overall, original is safer bet as mods for HL1 will work with original, not Source remake. But Source one isn't bad either. Much better looking today, at 2014 year thanks to engine updates, while at time of release it didn't look like it added much.

Deathmatch multiplayer part of remake was released after single-player part and comes by default with bundle on Steam... But let's just say, it's dead and not worth checking out.

P.S. I approve ability to start at any chapter, easier to pick up.
